comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content: Great vintage from County Tip '.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: It looks as if it still could be a GSWR J15 for 184 has similar looking outside springs on her tender. www.steamtrainsireland.com/locomotives/loco184.htm

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: They could be the railway men in the Quiet Man!

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: Lovely photo NLI. CIE owned hundreds of these little tenders, almost all were identical to each other. It would be highly unlikely that this is the tender 184 carries today. It is however unusual that the tender is numbered. Maybe it was paired with loco 123 in this photo or sometime over it's long lifespan.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
I don't think there's any suggestion that the loco in this picture (of which we can see about two inches) is 184 particularly, though I suppose the odds are 1 in 111 as it is a J15 tender.. The tenders do seem to have been numbered separately from the engines if I've understood the RPSI website correctly (50:50, I'm sure).

Edit: a lot less than 50:50, by the looks of it.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If it does belong to engine 123, this is it (a J15):

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] Looking at the other 1960's CIE steam engines in the photostream, You're right; They're mostly not numbered, so maybe this does belong to number 123 above.

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] You're very right. But are you sure 123 was a J15? It also looks quiet like a J18, judging by the dome.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] Not even slightly. I know bugger-all about this. I'm just going by photos, RPSI, wikipedia and deductions. I reckoned with all three wheels the same size and with what I took to be a J15 tender, the engine was a J15, but that's scarcely definitive. If you actually know about trains, the floor is all yours.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Which is of course not to say that you're not free to expound at length without being an expert. I do it every day.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] ..... standing next to Tom Crowe ???........ sure doesn't it look like it might be P Doherty himself........and he the foreman we saw greasing an engine up at Ballybrophy back in November 1960......twas too busy fighting over tenders they were to have noticed..:)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Doh! I thought that except I took Tom to be the chap on their right, not ours. Now I feel stupid again.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I didn't mean it was 184. It has a tender similar to 184. 123 in the other photo looks as if she's superheated just like 186 as seen in my photo - www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03/3638659222/in/photolis... The dome doesn't differ from 186.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] I know. I thought [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] was interpreting the pair of us to have said it was 184.

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13073434@N03] That's not a CIE J18! This is however: transportsofdelight.smugmug.com/RAILWAYS/IRISH-RAILWAYS/G...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Presumably we can look up some record and see what class 123 was.

comment.author: 88162413@N06
comment._content: It's a J15 I think, wouldn't be 100% though.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] Definitely a GS&WR Class 101 (J15) No other 0-6-0 engine had that curved hand rail on cab or stepped brake linkage beneath the con-rod.

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] I stand corrected on a M & GWR J18. 123 is definitely a J15.
